title: 15 prospects Patriots fans should know entering the 2026 NFL Combine
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots have 11 picks in the 2026 NFL Draft, including the 31st overall selection.
Patriots' draft needs include wide receiver, edge defender, and tight end, with KC Concepcion and Zion Young as key prospects.
Top prospects to watch for the Patriots include WR KC Concepcion, Edge Zion Young, and TE Kenyon Sadiq.

title: Malden school employee on leave after alleged ‘serious incident’ involving high school student
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Malden school employee is on leave after alleged serious incident involving a high school student.
Malden police are investigating the incident; no arrests made or charges filed as of now.
Incident allegedly occurred outside of working hours, involving Linden STEAM Academy employee.

title: These Mass. schools are closed for Wednesday, Feb. 25
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Massachusetts schools in South Coast and South Shore remain closed due to a historic snowstorm with three feet of snow.
School closures for Feb. 25 include Attleboro, Bridgewater-Raynham, Brockton, and Plymouth among others.
Some schools, such as Canton, King Philip Regional, and Wrentham, are delayed instead of fully closed.

title: MBTA to (mostly) resume normal weekday service after historic blizzard
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: MBTA will resume regular weekday service Wednesday, except the Fall River/New Bedford line which has a modified schedule.
MBTA General Manager thanked employees and riders for their efforts and patience during the storm recovery process.
Passengers are advised to plan for delays and exercise caution due to ongoing clean-up and possible weather impacts.

title: Curran: Patriots could ‘explore options’ to potentially upgrade from Stefon Diggs
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Stefon Diggs' future with the Patriots is uncertain due to his $26.5 million cap hit in 2026.
Patriots are considering restructuring Diggs' contract or exploring other wide receiver options, including Alec Pierce or A.J. Brown.
Diggs, 33 in November, has expressed a desire to stay, but his ongoing legal issues complicate his return.

title: Mass. representatives, including minority whip, to skip State of the Union address
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Massachusetts representatives, including Minority Whip Katherine Clark, will skip the State of the Union address in protest.
Rep. Ayanna Pressley plans to focus on immigrant children's plight, criticizing ICE's actions and Trump's policies.
Sen. Ed Markey and Rep. Jim McGovern also boycott, attending a rally instead to oppose Trump's address.

title: Will Charlie McAvoy, Jeremy Swayman be back in Bruins lineup when they resume play Thursday?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Charlie McAvoy and Jeremy Swayman won gold with Team USA in Olympic hockey, defeating Canada 2-1 in overtime.
Their return to the Bruins is uncertain due to travel disruptions from a blizzard and White House visit.
Bruins face Columbus Blue Jackets Thursday; potential goalie options include Swayman and Joonas Korpisalo.

title: Could Trent Williams suddenly emerge as a free-agent target for Patriots?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots face offensive line questions after Super Bowl LX loss, considering left tackle options.
Trent Williams, 49ers tackle, could become a free agent due to contract disagreements.
Williams, 37, would strengthen Patriots' line, despite high cost and short-term investment.

title: Boston ends snow emergency parking ban; residents can use space savers until Thursday evening
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Boston lifted the snow emergency and parking ban at 6 p.m. Tuesday following a blizzard.
Residents must remove vehicles from discounted garages by 8 p.m. to avoid regular rates.
Space savers must be removed by 6 p.m. Thursday, except in South End and Bay Village.

title: With more than 60 inches of snow this year, will the city dump its snow into Boston Harbor?
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston Mayor Michelle Wu's office confirmed the city will not dump snow into Boston Harbor this winter.
Boston will use 14 'snow farms' to manage over 60 inches of snow accumulated this season.
Snow dumping into Boston Harbor was banned in 1997 by the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection.
